elements.content: The ability to confine photoactive catalysts within metal–organic framework (MOF) materials affords the opportunity to expand the functional diversity of these materials into solar based applications. Here, the confinement of Ru(II)tris(2,2′-bipyridine) (RuBpy) by a MOF material derived from Zn(II) ions and trimesic acid (hereafter, USF2) is examined. Although the encapsulated RuBpy could not be crystallographically resolved within the MOF framework, the photophysical properties of the complex are characteristic of confinement including extended triplet metal-to-ligand (3MLCT) lifetime (τethanol = 614 ns and τUSF2 = 1.2 μs at 25 °C) and a slight hypsochromic shift in the steady-state emission spectrum relative to RuBpy in ethanol. The extended lifetime is attributed to a deactivation of a nonradiative 3dd that is antibonding with respect to the Ru(II)-bipyridine due to a confined molecular environment. These results represent one of the first examples of RuBpy encapsulation and photophysical characterization within a polyhedral MOF material.
elements.clean_text: The ability to confine photoactive catalysts within metal-organic framework (MOF) materials affords the opportunity to expand the functional diversity of these materials into solar based applications. Here, the confinement of Ru(II)tris(2,2'-bipyridine) (RuBpy) by a MOF material derived from Zn(II) ions and trimesic acid (hereafter, USF2) is examined. Although the encapsulated RuBpy could not be crystallographically resolved within the MOF framework, the photophysical properties of the complex are characteristic of confinement including extended triplet metal-to-ligand (3MLCT) lifetime (τethanol = 614 ns and τUSF2 = 1.2 μs at 25 °C) and a slight hypsochromic shift in the steady-state emission spectrum relative to RuBpy in ethanol. The extended lifetime is attributed to a deactivation of a nonradiative 3dd that is antibonding with respect to the Ru(II)-bipyridine due to a confined molecular environment. These results represent one of the first examples of RuBpy encapsulation and photophysical characterization within a polyhedral MOF material.

elements.content: Metal–organic framework (MOF) based materials provide excellent platforms through which to develop a wide range of functional applications. One such application is in the area of novel photocatalysts in which a photoactive metal cluster is encapsulated within the large cavities of the MOF. The high porosity of the MOF can facilitate small molecule diffusion into the large MOF cavities containing the photoexcited metal catalyst allowing for photochemical transformations to take place in high yields.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic framework (MOF) based materials provide excellent platforms through which to develop a wide range of functional applications. One such application is in the area of novel photocatalysts in which a photoactive metal cluster is encapsulated within the large cavities of the MOF. The high porosity of the MOF can facilitate small molecule diffusion into the large MOF cavities containing the photoexcited metal catalyst allowing for photochemical transformations to take place in high yields.

elements.content: Two general strategies have been employed in the development of MOFs as photocatalysts. The first utilizes the metal cluster building blocks and/or the ligands composing the framework as the photoactive component of the MOF. These photoactive framework MOFs typically contain lanthanide metal clusters, Ru(II)polypyridyl based clusters or porphyrin based organic linkers, which are all photochemically active. For example, numerous MOF materials have been synthesized and characterized that contain lanthanide or Ru(II) metal clusters as the building units. Many of these materials have been developed for sensor applications as the luminescent properties of lanthanide clusters are highly sensitive to the nature of coordinated ligands. Alternatively, recent advances have been made in the development of MOFs in which the ligands connecting the metal clusters are composed of either free base or metallo-porphyrins. These materials are of particular interest since the porphyrin macrocycles making up the framework contain open metal sites for catalysis and many photoactive porphyrin derivatives are available. In the case of framework based catalysts, the target reactant diffuses into the photoexcited framework, undergoes photochemical transformation at either the excited metal cluster or the excited ligands linking the metal clusters, followed by diffusion of the products from the framework. The advantages of this type of MOF photocatalyst include a high density of available catalytic sites, ease of access of photochemical reactants, and the ability to tune the framework to be selective for specific photochemical reactants. However, the drawbacks include nonspecific photochemistry as the reactants can simply react with surface sites on the solid (i.e., reducing the ability to utilize the MOF framework pores for chemical selectivity) and difficulty in design of reactive cavities that can impart high selectivity.
elements.clean_text: Two general strategies have been employed in the development of MOFs as photocatalysts. The first utilizes the metal cluster building blocks and/or the ligands composing the framework as the photoactive component of the MOF. These photoactive framework MOFs typically contain lanthanide metal clusters, Ru(II)polypyridyl based clusters or porphyrin based organic linkers, which are all photochemically active. For example, numerous MOF materials have been synthesized and characterized that contain lanthanide or Ru(II) metal clusters as the building units. Many of these materials have been developed for sensor applications as the luminescent properties of lanthanide clusters are highly sensitive to the nature of coordinated ligands. Alternatively, recent advances have been made in the development of MOFs in which the ligands connecting the metal clusters are composed of either free base or metallo-porphyrins. These materials are of particular interest since the porphyrin macrocycles making up the framework contain open metal sites for catalysis and many photoactive porphyrin derivatives are available. In the case of framework based catalysts, the target reactant diffuses into the photoexcited framework, undergoes photochemical transformation at either the excited metal cluster or the excited ligands linking the metal clusters, followed by diffusion of the products from the framework. The advantages of this type of MOF photocatalyst include a high density of available catalytic sites, ease of access of photochemical reactants, and the ability to tune the framework to be selective for specific photochemical reactants. However, the drawbacks include nonspecific photochemistry as the reactants can simply react with surface sites on the solid (i.e., reducing the ability to utilize the MOF framework pores for chemical selectivity) and difficulty in design of reactive cavities that can impart high selectivity.

elements.content: In contrast to photoactive MOF frameworks, photocatalytic MOFs have been developed in which a photoactive guest molecule is encapsulated within a MOF framework. Examples of this type of photocatalyst have been reported in which the encapsulated guest include a Keggin-type polyoxymetalate cluster encapsulated within an HKUST-1 framework, free-base and metallo-porphyrin encapsulated within both rhoZMOF and HKUST-1 framework and Ru(II)tris(2,2′-bipyridine)(RuBpy) encapsulated in pillared 2-D sheets and 3-D magnetic materials. In the case of encapsulated photocatalytic materials, the target reactants diffuse through available channels and cavities within the MOF, encounter the photoexcited catalyst, undergo photochemical transformation, and, subsequently, diffuse back through the pores/channels eventually exiting the material. This type of photocatalytic MOF offers a number of advantages including the fact that a wide array of existing photocatalysts can be exploited, reactant molecules must enter the pores of the MOF in order to react with the photocatalyst, thus allowing for selective chemistry to take place at specific sites within the MOF, and the large library of existing MOFs can be targeted with little need for new MOF designs or exotic ligands.
elements.clean_text: In contrast to photoactive MOF frameworks, photocatalytic MOFs have been developed in which a photoactive guest molecule is encapsulated within a MOF framework. Examples of this type of photocatalyst have been reported in which the encapsulated guest include a Keggin-type polyoxymetalate cluster encapsulated within an HKUST-1 framework, free-base and metallo-porphyrin encapsulated within both rhoZMOF and HKUST-1 framework and Ru(II)tris(2,2'-bipyridine)(RuBpy) encapsulated in pillared 2-D sheets and 3-D magnetic materials. In the case of encapsulated photocatalytic materials, the target reactants diffuse through available channels and cavities within the MOF, encounter the photoexcited catalyst, undergo photochemical transformation, and, subsequently, diffuse back through the pores/channels eventually exiting the material. This type of photocatalytic MOF offers a number of advantages including the fact that a wide array of existing photocatalysts can be exploited, reactant molecules must enter the pores of the MOF in order to react with the photocatalyst, thus allowing for selective chemistry to take place at specific sites within the MOF, and the large library of existing MOFs can be targeted with little need for new MOF designs or exotic ligands.

elements.content: Here, the first example of a RuBpy photocatalyst confined within a polyhedral MOF is reported. The RuBpy complex is ideal for the development of MOF based photocatalysts since this complex is very robust, the photophysical properties are well understood, and numerous photocatalytic reactions involving the RuBpy complex have been reported.
elements.clean_text: Here, the first example of a RuBpy photocatalyst confined within a polyhedral MOF is reported. The RuBpy complex is ideal for the development of MOF based photocatalysts since this complex is very robust, the photophysical properties are well understood, and numerous photocatalytic reactions involving the RuBpy complex have been reported.

elements.content: The polyhedral USF2 framework was prepared by carefully layering 10 mL of a solution containing 0.110 g of 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylate (BTCA) and 0.220 g of Zn(II)(NO3)2·6H2O in methanol over 10 mL of toluene containing 230 μL of analine in a 25 mL scintillation vial. After ∼2 days, clear crystals are formed on the side of the vial. The solution was then decanted and the crystals collected by centrifugation. The crystals were then washed extensively with ethanol. The corresponding RuBpy:USF2 material was prepared as per USF2 with the exception that 25 mg of RuBpy was added to the methanol solution containing the BTCA and Zn(II)(NO3)2·6H2O. After two days, dark orange crystals formed and were collected and extensively washed as per USF2. Several solvents were used to wash the RuBpy:USF2MOF to ensure no adventitiously bound RuBpy remained on the crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

Synthesis of USF2 and RuBpy:USF2

The polyhedral USF2 framework was prepared by carefully layering 10 mL of a solution containing 0.110 g of 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylate (BTCA) and 0.220 g of Zn(II)(NO3)2⋅6H2O in methanol over 10 mL of toluene containing 230 μL of analine in a 25 mL scintillation vial. After ~2 days, clear crystals are formed on the side of the vial. The solution was then decanted and the crystals collected by centrifugation. The crystals were then washed extensively with ethanol. The corresponding RuBpy:USF2 material was prepared as per USF2 with the exception that 25 mg of RuBpy was added to the methanol solution containing the BTCA and Zn(II)(NO3)2⋅6H2O. After two days, dark orange crystals formed and were collected and extensively washed as per USF2. Several solvents were used to wash the RuBpy:USF2MOF to ensure no adventitiously bound RuBpy remained on the crystals.

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction data for orange USF2-RuBpy MOF crystals were collected using synchrotron radiation, λ = 0.40656 Å, at the Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Lab, Argonne, Il. Indexing was performed using APEX2. Data integration and reduction were performed using SaintPlus 6.01. Absorption correction was performed by a multiscan method implemented in SADABS. The space group was determined using XPREP implemented in APEX2. The structure was solved using SHELXS-97, expanded using Fourier methods, and refined on F 2 using nonlinear least-squares techniques with SHELXL-97 contained in APEX2 and WinGX v1.70.01 program packages. RuBPY cation could not be resolved in the structure due to the positional disorder. The contribution of disordered content was treated as diffuse using the Squeeze procedure implemented in the Platon program (details are in the ).
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

The X-ray diffraction data for orange USF2-RuBpy MOF crystals were collected using synchrotron radiation, λ = 0.40656 Å, at the Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Lab, Argonne, Il. Indexing was performed using APEX2. Data integration and reduction were performed using SaintPlus 6.01. Absorption correction was performed by a multiscan method implemented in SADABS. The space group was determined using XPREP implemented in APEX2. The structure was solved using SHELXS-97, expanded using Fourier methods, and refined on F 2 using nonlinear least-squares techniques with SHELXL-97 contained in APEX2 and WinGX v1.70.01 program packages. RuBPY cation could not be resolved in the structure due to the positional disorder. The contribution of disordered content was treated as diffuse using the Squeeze procedure implemented in the Platon program (details are in the ).

elements.content: Optical spectra of both RuBpy in ethanol and the RuBpy:USF2MOF suspension were obtained using a ShimadzuUV24000 spectrometer in a 1 cm stirred quartz optical cuvette. The RuBpy:USF2MOF samples were sonicated and then washed three times with ethanol prior to use. This produced a very fine suspension of RuBpy:USF2 particles suitable for optical spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Spectroscopy

Optical spectra of both RuBpy in ethanol and the RuBpy:USF2MOF suspension were obtained using a ShimadzuUV24000 spectrometer in a 1 cm stirred quartz optical cuvette. The RuBpy:USF2MOF samples were sonicated and then washed three times with ethanol prior to use. This produced a very fine suspension of RuBpy:USF2 particles suitable for optical spectroscopy.

elements.content: The excited state properties of both the RuBpy in ethanol solution and the solid RuBpy:USF2 were probed using steady-state and time-resolved emission techniques. For steady-state emission studies, samples of the solid materials (several milligrams) were immobilized onto glass microscope slides by a thin layer of vacuum grease. The glass slides were then placed into a 1 cm quartz optical cuvette, and the emission spectra were collected using an ISS PC1 spectrofluorimeter (emission spectra are obtained 45° relative to the excitation beam using 452 nm excitation). Polarization measurements were also obtained using the PC1 in polarization mode using 452 nm excitation and the emission monochromator set to 598 nm. The polarization values were the average of 25 individual measurements. For emission lifetimes, a similar sample protocol was utilized. The immobilized solid state sample/cuvette was placed into a variable temperature sample holder and excited by a 532 nm 7 ns laser pulse (Continuum MiniLite II frequency doubled Nd:YAG laser, 1 mJ/pulse). The resulting emission was collected using a focusing optic and focused onto an EOT amplified Si photodiode (∼200 ps rise time) and digitized using a 4 GHz transient digitizer (Tektronix 7404). The data was processed using Origin8 software.
elements.clean_text:
Steady-State and Time-Resolved Emission

The excited state properties of both the RuBpy in ethanol solution and the solid RuBpy:USF2 were probed using steady-state and time-resolved emission techniques. For steady-state emission studies, samples of the solid materials (several milligrams) were immobilized onto glass microscope slides by a thin layer of vacuum grease. The glass slides were then placed into a 1 cm quartz optical cuvette, and the emission spectra were collected using an ISS PC1 spectrofluorimeter (emission spectra are obtained 45° relative to the excitation beam using 452 nm excitation). Polarization measurements were also obtained using the PC1 in polarization mode using 452 nm excitation and the emission monochromator set to 598 nm. The polarization values were the average of 25 individual measurements. For emission lifetimes, a similar sample protocol was utilized. The immobilized solid state sample/cuvette was placed into a variable temperature sample holder and excited by a 532 nm 7 ns laser pulse (Continuum MiniLite II frequency doubled Nd:YAG laser, 1 mJ/pulse). The resulting emission was collected using a focusing optic and focused onto an EOT amplified Si photodiode (~200 ps rise time) and digitized using a 4 GHz transient digitizer (Tektronix 7404). The data was processed using Origin8 software.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies of the orange RuBpy:USF2MOF crystals confirmed the close structural similarity between RuBpy:USF2MOF and USF2MOF (USF2MOF was first reported by Lu et al.). The crystal structure of RuBpy:USF2MOF has been determined to have Pm3̅m cubic symmetry with a = 20.251(2) Å and formula for the framework being Zn22(C9H3O6)12(H2O, MeOH)38. The diffraction data has been collected using synchrotron radiation, and the structure has been solved and refined. Interestingly, the RuBPY could not be visualized most likely due to translational and orientational disorder. However, the presence of the RuBpy cluster is demonstrated through the photophysical properties of the RuBpy chromophore within the USF2 material. The structure of USF2MOF/RuBpy:USF2MOF is formed through the assembly of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate anions and zinc(II) cations into a 3D polymeric framework that can be represented as a fusion of two faceted polyhedra (cubicuboctahedron, green; octahemioctahedron, orange) and an edge skeleton cube (pink) [Figure ]. The large amount of free space (∼68% with no free solvent present) in the structure allows the RuBPY cation to be encapsulated most likely in the largest cubooctahedral cavity (green).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of USF2 and RuBpy:USF2

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies of the orange RuBpy:USF2MOF crystals confirmed the close structural similarity between RuBpy:USF2MOF and USF2MOF (USF2MOF was first reported by Lu et al.). The crystal structure of RuBpy:USF2MOF has been determined to have Pm3̅m cubic symmetry with a = 20.251(2) Å and formula for the framework being Zn22(C9H3O6)12(H2O, MeOH)38. The diffraction data has been collected using synchrotron radiation, and the structure has been solved and refined. Interestingly, the RuBPY could not be visualized most likely due to translational and orientational disorder. However, the presence of the RuBpy cluster is demonstrated through the photophysical properties of the RuBpy chromophore within the USF2 material. The structure of USF2MOF/RuBpy:USF2MOF is formed through the assembly of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate anions and zinc(II) cations into a 3D polymeric framework that can be represented as a fusion of two faceted polyhedra (cubicuboctahedron, green; octahemioctahedron, orange) and an edge skeleton cube (pink) [Figure ]. The large amount of free space (~68% with no free solvent present) in the structure allows the RuBPY cation to be encapsulated most likely in the largest cubooctahedral cavity (green).

elements.content: Structural diagram of USF2-MOF illustrating the types of polyhedral cavities present for RuBpy encapsulation.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structural diagram of USF2-MOF illustrating the types of polyhedral cavities present for RuBpy encapsulation.

elements.content: Although single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies could not identify the location of the RuBpy complex within the USF2 structure, the complex exhibits distinct optical properties relative to RuBpy in ethanol solution. The absorption spectrum of RuBpy in solution exhibits two prominent absorption bands centered at 290 nm (ε = 85 mM–1 cm–1) and 452 nm (15 mM–1 cm–1) originating from a ligand centered π → π* transition (290 nm) and a metal-centered t2g to ligand centered π* transition (452 nm). The spectra of RuBpy:USF2 suspensions and the solution spectrum of RuBpy in ethanol are displayed in Figure . The spectra of the suspension demonstrate a clear bathochromic shift in the absorption band assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer state (3MLCT) relative to that in ethanol solution (452 nm in ethanol versus ∼472 nm for RuBpy:USF2). Figure also displays the excitation spectrum for the RuBpy:USF2, which has a maximum near ∼464 nm with a smaller band centered at ∼420 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Steady-State Optical Properties of RuBpy:USF2

Although single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies could not identify the location of the RuBpy complex within the USF2 structure, the complex exhibits distinct optical properties relative to RuBpy in ethanol solution. The absorption spectrum of RuBpy in solution exhibits two prominent absorption bands centered at 290 nm (ε = 85 mM-1 cm-1) and 452 nm (15 mM-1 cm-1) originating from a ligand centered π → π* transition (290 nm) and a metal-centered t2g to ligand centered π* transition (452 nm). The spectra of RuBpy:USF2 suspensions and the solution spectrum of RuBpy in ethanol are displayed in Figure . The spectra of the suspension demonstrate a clear bathochromic shift in the absorption band assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer state (3MLCT) relative to that in ethanol solution (452 nm in ethanol versus ~472 nm for RuBpy:USF2). Figure  also displays the excitation spectrum for the RuBpy:USF2, which has a maximum near ~464 nm with a smaller band centered at ~420 nm.

elements.content: Overlay of the absorption spectrum of RuBpy in ethanol (dotted line), a suspension of RuBpy:USF2 (solid line), and the excitation spectrum (measured at a peak emission of 598 nm) (dashed line).
elements.clean_text: 2  Overlay of the absorption spectrum of RuBpy in ethanol (dotted line), a suspension of RuBpy:USF2 (solid line), and the excitation spectrum (measured at a peak emission of 598 nm) (dashed line).

elements.content: The bathochromic shift observed in the RuBpy:USF material relative to RuBpy in solution is similar to that observed for RuBpy encapsulated within the cavities of zeolite Y as well as intercalated into zirconium phosphates. The origin of the bathochromic shift is not well understood. In the case of RuBpy encapsulated within zeolite Y, the shift has been attributed to intercavity RuBpy–RuBpy interactions, stabilization of the 1MLCT state by the polar cavity environment or restricted solvent–RuBpy excited state reorganization within the cavity. As the optical absorption spectra do not show any significant changes with RuBpy loading (data not shown) RuBpy–RuBpy interactions are not likely responsible for the observed shift within the RuBpy:USF2 material. However, the RuBpy 1MLCT state exhibits a dipole moment of ∼6.7 D, and thus, solvent reorganization/cavity polarity will have a significant effect in stabilizing the excited state. One of the unique properties of USF2 is that the cavities are cationic as the framework is composed of [M(II)2(−OOC−)4] units together with [M(II)2(−OOC−)3] units carrying a +1 charge. Thus, it is quite likely that the charged interior of the polyhedral cavities stabilizes the large dipole moment of the RuBpy 1MLCT resulting in the bathochromic shift in the absorption band.
elements.clean_text: The bathochromic shift observed in the RuBpy:USF material relative to RuBpy in solution is similar to that observed for RuBpy encapsulated within the cavities of zeolite Y as well as intercalated into zirconium phosphates. The origin of the bathochromic shift is not well understood. In the case of RuBpy encapsulated within zeolite Y, the shift has been attributed to intercavity RuBpy-RuBpy interactions, stabilization of the 1MLCT state by the polar cavity environment or restricted solvent-RuBpy excited state reorganization within the cavity. As the optical absorption spectra do not show any significant changes with RuBpy loading (data not shown) RuBpy-RuBpy interactions are not likely responsible for the observed shift within the RuBpy:USF2 material. However, the RuBpy 1MLCT state exhibits a dipole moment of ~6.7 D, and thus, solvent reorganization/cavity polarity will have a significant effect in stabilizing the excited state. One of the unique properties of USF2 is that the cavities are cationic as the framework is composed of [M(II)2(-OOC-)4] units together with [M(II)2(-OOC-)3] units carrying a +1 charge. Thus, it is quite likely that the charged interior of the polyhedral cavities stabilizes the large dipole moment of the RuBpy 1MLCT resulting in the bathochromic shift in the absorption band.

elements.content: The origin of the small hypsochromic shift between the excitation spectrum (598 nm emission maximum) and the absorption band is not clear. The excitation spectrum represents excitation into 1MLCT states that decay to the lower manifold of 3MLCT states leading to the 598 nm emission. The lack of emission from the longer wavelength absorption region would indicate a set of 1MLCT states, which have predominately nonradiate decay channels. These states are currently under investigation.
elements.clean_text: The origin of the small hypsochromic shift between the excitation spectrum (598 nm emission maximum) and the absorption band is not clear. The excitation spectrum represents excitation into 1MLCT states that decay to the lower manifold of 3MLCT states leading to the 598 nm emission. The lack of emission from the longer wavelength absorption region would indicate a set of 1MLCT states, which have predominately nonradiate decay channels. These states are currently under investigation.

elements.content: The corresponding normalized steady-state emission spectra of RuBpy in ethanol and the RuBpy:USF2 material is displayed in Figure . The spectrum of the RuBpy:USF2 displays a slight hypsochromic shift relative to that of the RuBpy in solution (604 nm for RuBpy in EtOH versus 598 nm for RuBpy in USF2). A similar shift has been observed for RuBpy encapsulated within zeolite Y as well as intercalated between bilayers of zirconium phosphate. The small shift of the emission band to higher energy is consistent with the rigidochromic effect. As discussed, the RuBpy has a large dipole moment in the excited state, which results in significant solvent reorganization around the emitting 3MLCT state. Rapid solvent reorganization facilitates relaxation of the Franck–Condon excited state to the thermally relaxed 1MLCT and intersystem crossing to the thermally relaxed 3MLCT emissive state. In the case of RuBpy confined within a solvent restricted environment (e.g., zeolite Y, zirconium phopshate, or USF2), solvent reorganization cannot take place. Thus, thermal relaxation of the Franck–Condon 1MLCT excited state does not take place, and emission arises from an unrelaxed 3MLCT state.
elements.clean_text: The corresponding normalized steady-state emission spectra of RuBpy in ethanol and the RuBpy:USF2 material is displayed in Figure . The spectrum of the RuBpy:USF2 displays a slight hypsochromic shift relative to that of the RuBpy in solution (604 nm for RuBpy in EtOH versus 598 nm for RuBpy in USF2). A similar shift has been observed for RuBpy encapsulated within zeolite Y as well as intercalated between bilayers of zirconium phosphate. The small shift of the emission band to higher energy is consistent with the rigidochromic effect. As discussed, the RuBpy has a large dipole moment in the excited state, which results in significant solvent reorganization around the emitting 3MLCT state. Rapid solvent reorganization facilitates relaxation of the Franck-Condon excited state to the thermally relaxed 1MLCT and intersystem crossing to the thermally relaxed 3MLCT emissive state. In the case of RuBpy confined within a solvent restricted environment (e.g., zeolite Y, zirconium phopshate, or USF2), solvent reorganization cannot take place. Thus, thermal relaxation of the Franck-Condon 1MLCT excited state does not take place, and emission arises from an unrelaxed 3MLCT state.

elements.content: Normalized steady-state emission spectra for RuBpy in ethanol (solid line) and RuBpy:USF2 material. Excitation wavelength, 450 nm.
elements.clean_text: 3  Normalized steady-state emission spectra for RuBpy in ethanol (solid line) and RuBpy:USF2 material. Excitation wavelength, 450 nm.

elements.content: An overlay of the emission decay profiles for RuBpy in ethanol and the RuBpy:USF2 material under anaerobic conditions is displayed in Figure . Both decay profiles can be fit to single exponential functions giving lifetimes of 614 ns and 1.2 μs, respectively, for RuBpy in ethanol and RuBpy:USF2.
elements.clean_text:
Emission Lifetimes

An overlay of the emission decay profiles for RuBpy in ethanol and the RuBpy:USF2 material under anaerobic conditions is displayed in Figure . Both decay profiles can be fit to single exponential functions giving lifetimes of 614 ns and 1.2 μs, respectively, for RuBpy in ethanol and RuBpy:USF2.

elements.content: Overlay of the normalized emission decays for RuBpy in ethanol and encapsulated within USF2. The samples were excited at 532 nm.
elements.clean_text: 4  Overlay of the normalized emission decays for RuBpy in ethanol and encapsulated within USF2. The samples were excited at 532 nm.

elements.content: The observed emission lifetimes for RuBpy type complexes can be rationalized using the excited state decay pathway summarized in Figure . In general, the RuBpy 3MLCT state can be deactivated through radiative decay to the singlet ground state and nonradiative decay between either the 3MLCT or the 3dd (ligand field) states according to k obs = k o + k 1 exp ( − Δ E 1 / R T ) where k o is the sum of the radiative and nonradiative rate constants for the lowest energy 3MLCT state (k o = k r + k nr), k 1 is the nonradiative rate constant for the 3dd decay, and ΔE 1 is the energy gap between the 3MLCT and 3dd states. The change in ΔE 1 can be quantified by plotting the temperature dependence of the observed emission decay rate constants as a function of temperature and fitting the data to eq (Figure ). In ethanol, RuBpy exhibits values of 3661 cm–1, 5.64 × 105 s–1, and 5.14 × 1013 s–1 for ΔE 1, k o, and k 1, respectively. In the case of the RuBpy:USF2 material, the value of ΔE 1 shifts to 4593 cm–1 with a k o of 5.5 × 105 s–1 and k 1 of 1.52 × 1015 s–1.

The change in ΔE 1 can be quantified by plotting the temperature dependence of the observed emission decay rate constants as a function of temperature and fitting the data to eq  (Figure ). In ethanol, RuBpy exhibits values of 3661 cm-1, 5.64 × 105 s-1, and 5.14 × 1013 s-1 for ΔE 1, k o, and k 1, respectively. In the case of the RuBpy:USF2 material, the value of ΔE 1 shifts to 4593 cm-1 with a k o of 5.5 × 105 s-1 and k 1 of 1.52 × 1015 s-1.

elements.clean_text: 5  Diagram illustrating the excited state decay pathways for the RuBpy complex.

elements.content: Top: overlay of the emission decays for RuBpy:USF2 as a function of temperature. Bottom: fits of the observed rate constants for RuBpy emission decay in ethanol (squares) or USF2 (circles) versus 1/T to eq .
elements.clean_text: 6  Top: overlay of the emission decays for RuBpy:USF2 as a function of temperature. Bottom: fits of the observed rate constants for RuBpy emission decay in ethanol (squares) or USF2 (circles) versus 1/T to eq .

elements.content: For RuBpy encapsulated within the super cages of zeolite Y, the observed excited state lifetime is nearly the same as in solution (∼530 ns in zeolite Y versus ∼600 ns in water) with a ΔE 1 value of ∼890 cm–1. The relatively low value of ΔE 1, relative to RuBpy in solution, was taken to indicate an increase in the energy gap between the 3MLCT manifold and the 3dd state such that the 3dd state could no longer be thermally populated. This is due to the fact that the 3dd state involves antibonding orbitals of the Ru–N bonds and population of this state results in expansion of the RuBpy complex. For zeolite Y, the cavity diameter of the super cage is ∼13 Å, while the diameter of the RuBpy complex is ∼12 Å, which limits the ability of the complex to expand in the excited state. The 890 cm–1 energy gap was assigned to a fourth 3MLCT state, which lies slightly above the 3MLCT manifold. The rate constant for the decay of the fourth 3MLCT is on the order of 107, which keeps the observed decay constant on the order of ∼500 ns. In contrast, encapsulation of the mixed ligand systems of the type Ru(II)bis(2,2′-bipyridine)(daf) (daf = diazafluorene) results in a significant increase in the emission lifetime and an increase in the 3MLCT–3dd energy gap by ∼1730 cm–1. Since the daf ligand has a weaker field strength than bipyridine, it was argued that the 3dd state lies much lower in energy in the Ru(II)bis(2,2′-bipyridine)(daf) complex giving rise to a much shorter emission lifetime in solution. Encapsulation then restricts the Ru–N bond length expansion upon population of the 3dd state, thereby increasing both ΔE 1 and the emission lifetime.
elements.clean_text: For RuBpy encapsulated within the super cages of zeolite Y, the observed excited state lifetime is nearly the same as in solution (~530 ns in zeolite Y versus ~600 ns in water) with a ΔE 1 value of ~890 cm-1. The relatively low value of ΔE 1, relative to RuBpy in solution, was taken to indicate an increase in the energy gap between the 3MLCT manifold and the 3dd state such that the 3dd state could no longer be thermally populated. This is due to the fact that the 3dd state involves antibonding orbitals of the Ru-N bonds and population of this state results in expansion of the RuBpy complex. For zeolite Y, the cavity diameter of the super cage is ~13 Å, while the diameter of the RuBpy complex is ~12 Å, which limits the ability of the complex to expand in the excited state. The 890 cm-1 energy gap was assigned to a fourth 3MLCT state, which lies slightly above the 3MLCT manifold. The rate constant for the decay of the fourth 3MLCT is on the order of 107, which keeps the observed decay constant on the order of ~500 ns. In contrast, encapsulation of the mixed ligand systems of the type Ru(II)bis(2,2'-bipyridine)(daf) (daf = diazafluorene) results in a significant increase in the emission lifetime and an increase in the 3MLCT-3dd energy gap by ~1730 cm-1. Since the daf ligand has a weaker field strength than bipyridine, it was argued that the 3dd state lies much lower in energy in the Ru(II)bis(2,2'-bipyridine)(daf) complex giving rise to a much shorter emission lifetime in solution. Encapsulation then restricts the Ru-N bond length expansion upon population of the 3dd state, thereby increasing both ΔE 1 and the emission lifetime.

elements.content: In the case of RuBpy encapsulated within USF2, the cubicuboctahedron cage of USF2 has a diameter of ∼14 Å with 9 Å windows (the smaller cavity of the USF2MOF has an inside diameter of ∼11.5 Å and thus not likely to accommodate the RuBpy cluster). The fact that the cage diameter of USF2 is slightly larger than that of the zeolite Y super cages may allow for some degree of expansion of the complex upon population of 3dd state. This is supported by the ΔE 1 value of 4593 cm–1 and k 1 of 1.5 × 1015 s–1, which clearly indicate that the thermally activated state is the 3dd and not a fourth 3MLCT as observed in the RuBpy–zeolite Y system. Attempts to fit the temperature dependence data to two exponential processes was not successful indicating that the 3MLCT states could not be thermally resolved.
elements.clean_text: In the case of RuBpy encapsulated within USF2, the cubicuboctahedron cage of USF2 has a diameter of ~14 Å with 9 Å windows (the smaller cavity of the USF2MOF has an inside diameter of ~11.5 Å and thus not likely to accommodate the RuBpy cluster). The fact that the cage diameter of USF2 is slightly larger than that of the zeolite Y super cages may allow for some degree of expansion of the complex upon population of 3dd state. This is supported by the ΔE 1 value of 4593 cm-1 and k 1 of 1.5 × 1015 s-1, which clearly indicate that the thermally activated state is the 3dd and not a fourth 3MLCT as observed in the RuBpy-zeolite Y system. Attempts to fit the temperature dependence data to two exponential processes was not successful indicating that the 3MLCT states could not be thermally resolved.

elements.content: The most significant difference between the RuBpy–USF2 system and RuBpy in ethanol or the Ru(II)bis(2,2′-bipyridine)(daf)–zeolite Y is the magnitude of the 3dd decay constant. For the RuBpy–USF2 system, k 1 is nearly 2 orders of magnitude larger (1.5 × 1015 s–1 for RuBpy:USF2 versus ∼5 × 1013 s–1 for RuBpy in ethanol, 8 × 1011 s–1 for Ru(II)bis(2,2′-bipyridine)(daf)-zeolite Y, and 8.5 × 1014 for Ru(II)bis(2,2′-bipyridine)(daf) in ethanol/methanol). In general, the nonradiative decay rate constant can be described through the energy gap law: k nr ∝ exp ( − γ E 0 / ℏ ω M ) γ = ln ( E 0 / S M ℏ ω M ) − 1 S M = m ( 1 / 2 ) ( M ω M / ℏ ) ( Δ Q e ) 2 where E o is the energy gap, ℏωm is the average energy of the vibrational mode (or modes) that couple the excited and ground states, S M is the Huang–Rhys factor describing the degree to which the excited and ground states are vibronically coupled, M is the reduced massl and ΔQ e is the difference between the ground and excited state equilibrium geometries. Generally, eq predicts that an increase in gap energy will lower k nr provided the coupling modes and ground/excited state geometries remain unchanged. The fact that k nr increases by roughly 2 orders of magnitude for RuBpy encapsulated within USF2 relative to RuBpy in solution would then indicate that the equilibrium geometries of the ground/excited states and/or the coupling (accepting) mode has changed. In the case of RuBpy, the accepting mode originates from high frequency vibrations associated with the bipyridine ligands and are either C–C or C–H in character. These modes are unlikely to be significantly perturbed upon encapsulation (although this is currently under investigation). The fact that the cages of USF2 appear to restrict the expansion of the 3dd the excited would indicate that SM is perturbed between the RuBpy in solution and the encapsulated complex due to the ΔQ e term. Thus, the effect of encapsulation is to not only raise ΔE 1 but also increase k nr through excited state geometric distortions.
elements.clean_text: The most significant difference between the RuBpy-USF2 system and RuBpy in ethanol or the Ru(II)bis(2,2'-bipyridine)(daf)-zeolite Y is the magnitude of the 3dd decay constant. For the RuBpy-USF2 system, k 1 is nearly 2 orders of magnitude larger (1.5 × 1015 s-1 for RuBpy:USF2 versus ~5 × 1013 s-1 for RuBpy in ethanol, 8 × 1011 s-1 for Ru(II)bis(2,2'-bipyridine)(daf)-zeolite Y, and 8.5 × 1014 for Ru(II)bis(2,2'-bipyridine)(daf) in ethanol/methanol). In general, the nonradiative decay rate constant can be described through the energy gap law: 2    k   nr   ∝ exp  ( - γ   E   0   / ℏ   ω   M   )     3  γ = ln  (   E   0   /   S   M   ℏ   ω   M   )  - 1    4    S   M   = m  ( 1 / 2 )   ( M   ω   M   / ℏ )    ( Δ   Q   e   )   2    where E o is the energy gap, ℏωm is the average energy of the vibrational mode (or modes) that couple the excited and ground states, S M is the Huang-Rhys factor describing the degree to which the excited and ground states are vibronically coupled, M is the reduced massl and ΔQ e is the difference between the ground and excited state equilibrium geometries. Generally, eq  predicts that an increase in gap energy will lower k nr provided the coupling modes and ground/excited state geometries remain unchanged. The fact that k nr increases by roughly 2 orders of magnitude for RuBpy encapsulated within USF2 relative to RuBpy in solution would then indicate that the equilibrium geometries of the ground/excited states and/or the coupling (accepting) mode has changed. In the case of RuBpy, the accepting mode originates from high frequency vibrations associated with the bipyridine ligands and are either C-C or C-H in character. These modes are unlikely to be significantly perturbed upon encapsulation (although this is currently under investigation). The fact that the cages of USF2 appear to restrict the expansion of the 3dd the excited would indicate that SM is perturbed between the RuBpy in solution and the encapsulated complex due to the ΔQ e term. Thus, the effect of encapsulation is to not only raise ΔE 1 but also increase k nr through excited state geometric distortions.

elements.content: The polarization associated with the excited state emission of RuBpy can provide additional insights into the effects of encapsulation on the excited state dynamics. The polarization value for RuBpy in ethanol is found to be 0.004 ± 0.001, while that for the RuBpy:USF2 complex is found to be 0.04 ± 0.01. The polarization is defined as ( 1 / P − 1 / 3 ) = ( 1 / P o − 1 / 3 ) ( 1 + τ / φ ) where P is the polarization, P o is the limiting polarization with no molecular rotation, τ is the natural lifetime, and φ is the rotational correlation time. The rotational correlation time is dependent upon the molecular volume and the solvent viscosity: φ = η V / R T Equations and demonstrate that the polarization value varies proportionally with molar volume and inversely with the natural lifetime of the emitter.
elements.clean_text:
Polarization

The polarization associated with the excited state emission of RuBpy can provide additional insights into the effects of encapsulation on the excited state dynamics. The polarization value for RuBpy in ethanol is found to be 0.004 ± 0.001, while that for the RuBpy:USF2 complex is found to be 0.04 ± 0.01. The polarization is defined as 5   ( 1 / P - 1 / 3 )  =  ( 1 /   P   o   - 1 / 3 )   ( 1 + τ / φ )   where P is the polarization, P o is the limiting polarization with no molecular rotation, τ is the natural lifetime, and φ is the rotational correlation time. The rotational correlation time is dependent upon the molecular volume and the solvent viscosity: 6  φ = η V / R T  Equations  and  demonstrate that the polarization value varies proportionally with molar volume and inversely with the natural lifetime of the emitter.

elements.content: For the RuBpy complex in solution emission from the 3MLCT of the 3E → 1A1 transition, which is a three-dimensional oscillator consisting of a strong planar component and a much weaker perpendicular component. In solution, the relatively long lifetime (∼600 ns) and fast rotational correlation time (0.1 ns) results in a polarization value near 0 (i.e., randomization of the planar oscillator). The fact that the polarization value increases by nearly a factor of 10 for the RuBpy:USF materials indicates a much more rotationally restrictive environment for the RuBpy. In fact, the polarization value of 0.04 for the RuBpy:USF2 closely matches that of RuBpy in glycerol:water (6:4 v/v) at −30 °C (P ≈ 0.05, η ≈ 9 cP). This would suggest either a highly viscous interior of the USF2 cavities or a restricted rotation due to interactions between the cavity and the excited state dipole moment of the 3MLCT restricting orientational averaging.
elements.clean_text: For the RuBpy complex in solution emission from the 3MLCT of the 3E → 1A1 transition, which is a three-dimensional oscillator consisting of a strong planar component and a much weaker perpendicular component. In solution, the relatively long lifetime (~600 ns) and fast rotational correlation time (0.1 ns) results in a polarization value near 0 (i.e., randomization of the planar oscillator). The fact that the polarization value increases by nearly a factor of 10 for the RuBpy:USF materials indicates a much more rotationally restrictive environment for the RuBpy. In fact, the polarization value of 0.04 for the RuBpy:USF2 closely matches that of RuBpy in glycerol:water (6:4 v/v) at -30 °C (P ~ 0.05, η ~ 9 cP). This would suggest either a highly viscous interior of the USF2 cavities or a restricted rotation due to interactions between the cavity and the excited state dipole moment of the 3MLCT restricting orientational averaging.

elements.content: In summary, the data presented here demonstrates the first successful attempt to encapsulate the photoactive Ru(II)tris(2,2′-bipyridine) within the cavities of a polyhedral metal organic framework. The effects of encapsulation are evident from changes in photophysical properties including an increase in the emission lifetime and 10-fold increase in emission polarization.
elements.clean_text:
Summary

In summary, the data presented here demonstrates the first successful attempt to encapsulate the photoactive Ru(II)tris(2,2'-bipyridine) within the cavities of a polyhedral metal organic framework. The effects of encapsulation are evident from changes in photophysical properties including an increase in the emission lifetime and 10-fold increase in emission polarization.

cln_elements.content: Although single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies could not identify the location of the RuBpy complex within the USF2 structure, the complex exhibits distinct optical properties relative to RuBpy in ethanol solution. The absorption spectrum of RuBpy in solution exhibits two prominent absorption bands centered at 290 nm (ε = 85 mM–1 cm–1) and 452 nm (15 mM–1 cm–1) originating from a ligand centered π → π* transition (290 nm) and a metal-centered t2g to ligand centered π* transition (452 nm). The spectra of RuBpy:USF2 suspensions and the solution spectrum of RuBpy in ethanol are displayed in Figure . The spectra of the suspension demonstrate a clear bathochromic shift in the absorption band assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer state (3MLCT) relative to that in ethanol solution (452 nm in ethanol versus ∼472 nm for RuBpy:USF2). Figure also displays the excitation spectrum for the RuBpy:USF2, which has a maximum near ∼464 nm with a smaller band centered at ∼420 nm.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Steady-State Optical Properties of RuBpy:USF2

Although single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies could not identify the location of the RuBpy complex within the USF2 structure, the complex exhibits distinct optical properties relative to RuBpy in ethanol solution. The absorption spectrum of RuBpy in solution exhibits two prominent absorption bands centered at 290 nm (ε = 85 mM-1 cm-1) and 452 nm (15 mM-1 cm-1) originating from a ligand centered π → π* transition (290 nm) and a metal-centered t2g to ligand centered π* transition (452 nm). The spectra of RuBpy:USF2 suspensions and the solution spectrum of RuBpy in ethanol are displayed in Figure . The spectra of the suspension demonstrate a clear bathochromic shift in the absorption band assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer state (3MLCT) relative to that in ethanol solution (452 nm in ethanol versus ~472 nm for RuBpy:USF2). Figure  also displays the excitation spectrum for the RuBpy:USF2, which has a maximum near ~464 nm with a smaller band centered at ~420 nm.

of Ru(II)tris(2,2′-bipyridine)
